content:
I'd like to try my hand at porting a little bit, could I have push access to mathlib4? (Github: @pimotte)

I'm guessing the best thing to start off for newbies is starting to port a new file? (Rather than picking up help-wanted PRs?)
@maintainers
@Pim Otte Hoi, welkom! https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/invitations
And yes, starting a new file is indeed recommended.
I suggest that you pick something that is not in the top-10 of unported files on https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib-port-status/
That should give you a stress-free way to get acquainted with the porting process.
Pim Otte has marked this topic as resolved.

I finally have some time to help with the port. I am thinking of porting Mathlib/Algebra/Category/Ring/Adjunctions.lean [looking for something else] to get familiar with the process: is there anything that I should be aware of?

Also, after start_port and getting the cache, the first step seems to be to push. Do I need permissions to do that? I have not tried, in case I am not supposed to...
If you don't have anything particular which you want to see ported, then take a look at the port progress thread and look at the "target files", click on the pdf and try a blue file.
Kevin is explaining that the blue files in those graphs are files for which someone has opened a port, but it hasn't been merged. It's much more helpful to work on these than to open new ports.
@Damiano Testa, yes, you should push.
I find the graphs generated by https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib-port-status/ easier to consume
Stupid question: how do you use the web page to make a graph? I've only ever seen it make a list of vertices necessary for a port, as it were.
Under the progress bar for a particular file, there is a drop down triangle for showing the graph
Oh nice! I was blissfully unaware that that functionality existed until 5 minutes ago.
The graph is not rendered by default because on some unported files it slows everything to a crawl
The one advantage to the PDF graphs is that they contain the greyed-out "unused dependency" nodes, which I decided were too expensive to compute for all 3000 files
Note there is even a linkifier, port-status#linear_algebra/clifford_algebra/basic#graph
@Kevin Buzzard @Scott Morrison Thanks for the info! I will then try to take on a file in-progress, once I am back at a computer with a working Lean 4.
I would also like to help at porting. Could I have push access to mathlib4? (Github: @QuinnLesquimau)
@maintainers
invite sent! Take a look at the porting wiki for tips and instructions: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/wiki/Porting-wiki
